Chief Complaint: hypotension
   24 Hour Events:

   Echo showed LVEF 35% with infero-septal, inferior and infero-lateral

   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2108-10-16**], regional
   LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD and at least moderate aortic stenosis
   are present (low output AS). Overall LVEF has decreased.
   Cath @2pm showed: CI 2.1, Fick CO 4.41. LMCA is short with 90% lesion.
   LAD has 90% lesion at ostium with segment mid disease to 70%. LCx is
   proximally occluded. RCA is a very large ectatic vessel with multiple
   lesions to 80%. No intervention performed. CT [**Doctor First Name 213**] consulted and would
   not do CABG at this time due to pulmonary status. Got Lasix 80 IV in
   cath lab and put out 300cc. Lasix gtt 5 mg/hr, titrate to UOP
   300cc/hr.  Received lasix 40 mg IV x 1 with good response.
   .
   Spiked to 102, cultures sent, changed anti-microbial regimen to
   vanc/cefepime/flagyl. Wary of septic physiology in setting of
   cardiogenic shock.
   .
   Lasix increased to 10 mg/hr, received additional bolus of lasix 80 mg
   IV x 1.  Weaning vent.

   Imaging: 1. No PE.
   2. Extensive bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground
   glass
   opacities. As the lung bases were clear on the study four hours prior,
   findings are concerning for aspiration and pulmonary edema.
   3. 6.5-cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No evidence for leak or
   rupture.
   4. Abnormal perfusion of the kidneys bilaterally likely relates to the
   phase of enhancement and repeated contrast administration.
   5. Diverticulosis. No evidence for diverticulitis
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with apparent hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.
   - Restart vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to optimize
   respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG.
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial presentation.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers.
   - TTE as above
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - Surface echocardiogram today.
   - Hold off on lasix pending determination of etiology to hypotension
   (cardiogenic versus distributive versus mixed).
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - Consider right heart cath to determine filling pressures and PCWP.
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch.
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.
   - Calcium gluconate, insulin, D50, bicarb, and kayexalate.
   - Repeat ECG.
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis.
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF
   ACCESS: PIV
   PPx: Heparin SQ, famotidine
   Code: Full (confirmed with HCP)
   Contact: [**Name (NI) 4858**] [**Name (NI) 2747**] (niece/HCP) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10188**] (h), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10189**] (c)
   Dispo: ICU level of care.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension, decreased cardiac output, and pulmonary edema suggest cardiogenic shock, which can be caused by cardiogenic heart failure, cardiac tamponade, or severe valvular disease.
2. Sepsis/SIRS: The patient's increased white blood cell count, fever, and signs of sepsis/SIRS physiology (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia) suggest the possibility of sepsis or SIRS, which can be caused by pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or other infections.
3. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's recent intubation and aspiration event during emergent intubation may have led to aspiration pneumonia, which can cause respiratory failure, sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction.
4. Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA): The patient's abdominal imaging shows an infrarenal AAA, which may be ruptured or leaking, causing hypotension, shock, and multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground glass opacities on imaging, along with his respiratory failure and hypoxemia, suggest the possibility of ARDS, which can be caused by pneumonia, sepsis, or other lung injuries.
6. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine and decreased urine output suggest AKI, which can be caused by hypotension, sepsis, or nephrotoxic medications.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium level may be caused by rhabdomyolysis, transfusion, or other factors, and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
8. Transaminitis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may be caused by hypotension, sepsis, or other factors, and can lead to liver dysfunction and multi-organ failure.
9. Mixed respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure may be caused by aspiration pneumonia, sepsis, or other factors, and can lead to respiratory failure and multi-organ dysfunction.
10. Septic shock: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of sepsis/SIRS physiology suggest the possibility of septic shock, which can be caused by sepsis, pneumonia, or other infections.

These potential medical complications highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of the patient's condition, as well as the need for further evaluation and treatment to address the underlying causes of his illness.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .

   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.

   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, admitted to the ICU for hypotension and respiratory failure. He has undergone several procedures, including echocardiography, cardiac catheterization, and intubation. His current condition is complex, with multiple potential etiologies for his hypotension, including cardiogenic shock, sepsis, and distributive shock.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible cardiac ischemia or infarction. His electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates dynamic changes, including ST-segment elevation in aVR and V1, which may indicate left main or proximal LAD ischemia. His cardiac catheterization results show significant coronary artery disease, including a 90% lesion in the left main coronary artery and 70% lesion in the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery.

The patient's respiratory status is also concerning, with mixed respiratory failure and possible aspiration pneumonia or chemical pneumonitis. His blood cultures are pending, and he is receiving antimicrobial therapy for suspected sepsis.

The patient's hemodynamic status is unstable, with a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg and a central venous pressure (CVP) of 12 mmHg. He is receiving vasopressors, including norepinephrine, to maintain his blood pressure.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may develop cardiogenic shock, which could lead to further decompensation and organ failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology may worsen, leading to multi-organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and he may develop further respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is already compromised, and he may develop AKI, which could lead to further decompensation and organ failure.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels may indicate rhabdomyolysis, which could lead to further muscle damage and organ failure.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium levels may indicate hyperkalemia, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and he may develop aspiration pneumonia, which could lead to further respiratory failure and organ failure.
8. Chemical pneumonitis: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and he may develop chemical pneumonitis, which could lead to further respiratory failure and organ failure.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.

   .

   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening

   - Trend fever curve, WBC

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department for hypotension and respiratory failure. The patient's condition has been complex and challenging to manage, with multiple potential etiologies for his symptoms.

The patient has a history of acute systolic heart failure, with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 35%. He has moderate to severe mitral regurgitation and aortic stenosis, which may be contributing to his symptoms. The patient also has a 6.5-cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, which may be a potential source of bleeding.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with mixed respiratory failure and significant hypoxia. He requires mechanical ventilation with a high level of support, and his oxygenation and ventilation have improved significantly with aggressive diuresis.

The patient's cardiac biomarkers are elevated, with a troponin T level of 2.68 and a creatine kinase (CK) level of 1099. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows dynamic changes, with ST-segment elevation in leads aVR and V1, which may indicate left main or proximal LAD ischemia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), indicating acute kidney injury and liver damage. His white blood cell count is elevated, and he has a fever, which may indicate an infectious process.

The patient's medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and metformin, which may be contributing to his symptoms. He has also received multiple blood transfusions, which may have caused volume overload and worsening of his cardiac function.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may be at risk for cardiogenic shock.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and fever may indicate an infectious process, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may be at risk for respiratory failure.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels indicate acute kidney injury, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medications.
5. Liver damage: The patient's elevated LDH level and transaminase levels indicate liver damage, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medications.

The patient's potential surgical complications include:

1. Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm: The patient's aneurysm is large and may be at risk for rupture.
2. Coronary artery bypass grafting: The patient's coronary artery disease may require surgical intervention.

The patient's potential complications related to his medications include:

1. Aspirin toxicity: The patient's aspirin use may cause toxicity, particularly in combination with other medications.
2. Statin toxicity: The patient's atorvastatin use may cause toxicity, particularly in combination with other medications.

The patient's potential complications related to his underlying medical conditions include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may be at risk for respiratory failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels indicate acute kidney injury, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medications.
4. Liver damage: The patient's elevated LDH level and transaminase levels indicate liver damage, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and challenging to manage, and he requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 91-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypotension and a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS), unstable angina, and coronary ischemia. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is on oxygen therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating myocardial infarction. The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia with ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVL, consistent with myocardial infarction.

The patient's imaging studies show extensive bilateral pulmonary air space consolidations and ground glass opacities, consistent with aspiration and pulmonary edema. The patient's abdominal imaging shows an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, but no evidence of leak or rupture.

The patient's physical examination shows a well-nourished male with a normal-sized heart, with a regular rhythm and a blood pressure of 106/73 mmHg. The patient's respiratory examination shows bilateral crackles and wheezing, consistent with pulmonary edema.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a differential count showing an increase in neutrophils. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) show elevated levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT), consistent with liver injury.

The patient's medical history includes a history of COPD, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient is taking medications for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and COPD.

Based on the patient's condition, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's diagnosis of ACS, unstable angina, and coronary ischemia puts him at risk for cardiac complications such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's diagnosis of pulmonary edema and aspiration puts him at risk for respiratory complications such as respiratory failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and pneumonia.
3. Renal complications: The patient's diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI) puts him at risk for renal complications such as chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
4. Infectious complications: The patient's diagnosis of septic shock and pneumonia puts him at risk for infectious complications such as sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diagnosis of stress ulcer puts him at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and pancreatitis.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's diagnosis of septic shock and cardiac complications puts him at risk for neurological complications such as encephalopathy, seizures, and stroke.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care should be implemented:

1. Cardiac care: The patient should be closely monitored for cardiac complications, and medications such as beta blockers and nitrates should be administered as needed.
2. Respiratory care: The patient should be closely monitored for respiratory complications, and medications such as bronchodilators and diuretics should be administered as needed.
3. Renal care: The patient should be closely monitored for renal complications, and medications such as diuretics and vasopressors should be administered as needed.
4. Infectious disease care: The patient should be closely monitored for infectious complications, and antibiotics should be administered as needed.
5. Gastrointestinal care: The patient should be closely monitored for gastrointestinal complications, and medications such as proton pump inhibitors and histamine-2 (H2) blockers should be administered as needed.
6. Neurological care: The patient should be closely monitored for neurological complications, and medications such as sedatives and analgesics should be administered as needed.

In conclusion, the patient is a 91-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome, unstable angina, and coronary ischemia. The patient is at risk for various medical complications, and a comprehensive plan of care should be implemented to manage these complications and improve the patient's outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning given signs of end
   organ perfusion including elevated creatinine, LFTs, and cardiac
   biomarkers.  Potential etiologies include cardiogenic shock or
   distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology, anaphylaxis in setting
   of receiving blood products, or medications.  Bedside echo by
   cardiology fellow in ED did not show decreased LVEF but with moderate
   to severe MR with unknown baseline, which if new could be the etiology
   to patient's symptoms.  In addition, volume rescucitation in setting of
   suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs and 3L IVF could also have
   caused volume overload leading to decreased cardiac output and
   pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.  SIRS/sepsis could be
   in the setting of aspiration event during emergent intubation or
   TRALI.
   - Treat as sepsis with EGDT for now. Maintain MAP>65, CVP>12
   (intubated), ScVO2>70, monitor UOP with goal>30 cc/hr. Recheck lactate.
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and pip/tazo pending sputum cultures. Can likely discontinue in 24-48
   hours when infectious process ruled out.
   - Obtain blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top.
   - Formal TTE in AM to assess for valvular disease, LVEF, and wall
   motion abnormalities.
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with apparent hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.
   - Restart vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to optimize
   respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG.
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial presentation.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers.
   - TTE as above
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - Surface echocardiogram today.
   - Hold off on lasix pending determination of etiology to hypotension
   (cardiogenic versus distributive versus mixed).
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - Consider right heart cath to determine filling pressures and PCWP.
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch.
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.
   - Calcium gluconate, insulin, D50, bicarb, and kayexalate.
   - Repeat ECG.
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis.
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .

   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning given signs of end
   organ perfusion including elevated creatinine, LFTs, and cardiac
   biomarkers.  Potential etiologies include cardiogenic shock or
   distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology, anaphylaxis in setting
   of receiving blood products, or medications.  Bedside echo by
   cardiology fellow in ED did not show decreased LVEF but with moderate
   to severe MR with unknown baseline, which if new could be the etiology
   to patient's symptoms.  In addition, volume rescucitation in setting of
   suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs and 3L IVF could also have
   caused volume overload leading to decreased cardiac output and
   pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.  SIRS/sepsis could be
   in the setting of aspiration event during emergent intubation or
   TRALI.
   - Treat as sepsis with EGDT for now. Maintain MAP>65, CVP>12
   (intubated), ScVO2>70, monitor UOP with goal>30 cc/hr. Recheck lactate.
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and pip/tazo pending sputum cultures. Can likely discontinue in 24-48
   hours when infectious process ruled out.
   - Obtain blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top.
   - Formal TTE in AM to assess for valvular disease, LVEF, and wall
   motion abnormalities.
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with apparent hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.
   - Restart vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to optimize
   respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG.
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial presentation.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers.
   - TTE as above
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - Surface echocardiogram today.
   - Hold off on lasix pending determination of etiology to hypotension
   (cardiogenic versus distributive versus mixed).
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - Consider right heart cath to determine filling pressures and PCWP.
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention

   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated

   - Calcium gluconate, insulin, D50, bicarb, and kayexalate.
   - Repeat ECG.

   - Trend LFTs
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypotension, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential underlying causes for his hypotension, including cardiogenic shock, distributive shock, and mixed shock.

The patient's cardiac status is concerning, with a low left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 35% and moderate to severe mitral regurgitation (MR). He has also had a significant increase in cardiac biomarkers, including troponin-T, which suggests possible cardiac ischemia or infarction.

The patient's respiratory status is also concerning, with mixed respiratory failure and significant auto-PEEP and breathstacking. He requires mechanical ventilation with a high inspiratory pressure and oxygen flow rate.

The patient's renal status is also concerning, with acute renal failure (ARF) and a significant increase in creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels.

The patient's metabolic status is also concerning, with hyperkalemia, transaminitis, and acidosis. He requires close monitoring and management of his electrolyte levels and acid-base status.

The patient's infectious status is also concerning, with a possible infectious etiology for his hypotension and respiratory failure. He has been treated with antibiotics and antifungals, and further testing is needed to determine the underlying cause of his infection.

The patient's hemodynamic status is also concerning, with a low mean arterial pressure (MAP) and a high central venous pressure (CVP). He requires close monitoring and management of his hemodynamic status to prevent further compromise of his cardiac and renal function.

The patient's overall condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management in the ICU to prevent further deterioration and to address the underlying causes of his hypotension, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: further decline in cardiac function, cardiac arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: further decline in lung function, respiratory failure, and respiratory arrest.
3. Renal complications: further decline in renal function, acute kidney injury, and chronic kidney disease.
4. Metabolic complications: further decline in electrolyte levels, acidosis, and hyperkalemia.
5. Infectious complications: further spread of infection, sepsis, and septic shock.
6. Hemodynamic complications: further decline in blood pressure, cardiac output, and perfusion of vital organs.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management in the ICU, including:

1. Cardiac monitoring: continuous electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring, cardiac enzymes, and echocardiogram.
2. Respiratory monitoring: continuous pulse oximetry, arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, and chest radiography.
3. Renal monitoring: serial creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, urine output, and urine electrolytes.
4. Metabolic monitoring: serial electrolyte levels, acid-base status, and glucose levels.
5. Infectious monitoring: serial blood cultures, urine cultures, and sputum cultures.
6. Hemodynamic monitoring: continuous blood pressure monitoring, central venous pressure (CVP) monitoring, and pulmonary artery catheterization.

The patient's treatment plan should include:

1. Cardiac medications: beta blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, and statins.
2. Respiratory medications: bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and antibiotics.
3. Renal medications: diuretics, vasopressors, and antibiotics.
4. Metabolic medications: insulin, dextrose, and bicarbonate.
5. Infectious medications: antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals.
6. Hemodynamic medications: vasopressors, inotropes, and diuretics.

The patient's family should be educated on his condition, treatment plan, and potential complications, and should be involved in his care and decision-making process.

You are a Medical Specialist capable of analyzing complex medical cases. To do that, you will carefully review the physician's daily progress note for a patient in the ICU detailing the patient's health progress in the ICU. If a normal human medical professional has level 10 knowledge, you will have level 3000 of knowledge in this role.    Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%,PEEP 18 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.
   - Telemetry, sinus tach;
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - Increase minute ventilation as above.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU for hypotension and respiratory failure. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His current condition is characterized by:

* Hypotension with a systolic blood pressure of 118 mmHg
* Respiratory failure with a respiratory rate of 6 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 398 mmHg
* Atrial flutter with a heart rate of 98 beats per minute
* Electrolyte imbalance with hyperkalemia (potassium level of 5.6 mmol/L) and hyperphosphatemia (phosphorus level of 4.2 mg/dL)
* Acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL
* Mixed respiratory failure with hypoxia and hypercarbia
* Coronary artery disease with a troponin level of 9.06 ng/mL
* Potential ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with moderate to severe mitral regurgitation (MR)

The patient is receiving aggressive diuresis with furosemide, vasopressors, and oxygen therapy. He is also receiving antibiotics for suspected aspiration pneumonia and chemical pneumonitis. The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and further management is planned based on his response to treatment.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ruptured AAA: The patient's symptoms and signs are concerning for a ruptured AAA, which could lead to hemorrhagic shock and death if not treated promptly.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and low cardiac output could be due to cardiogenic shock, which could worsen his condition if not treated promptly.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammatory markers could indicate sepsis, which could worsen his condition and lead to multiple organ dysfunction.
4. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and hypoxia could lead to ARDS, which could worsen his condition and lead to respiratory failure.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure could worsen his condition and lead to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease if not treated promptly.
6. Coronary artery disease: The patient's coronary artery disease could worsen his condition and lead to myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest if not treated promptly.
7. Infection: The patient's suspected aspiration pneumonia and chemical pneumonitis could lead to infection and worsen his condition if not treated promptly.
8. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and platelet dysfunction could lead to bleeding complications, which could worsen his condition if not treated promptly.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is a 67-inch tall, 91 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with hypotension. He has a history of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and is currently experiencing atrial flutter with frequent runs of atrial fibrillation. He has been treated with midazolam and fentanyl infusions, as well as lasix and levophed, which were discontinued. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.6°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 118/69 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 6 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100%.

The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial flutter with frequent runs of atrial fibrillation, and he has been treated with cardioversion attempts with 250 joules, which were unsuccessful. His cardiac output is compromised, and he has a high risk of developing cardiac arrest.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 6 inspirations per minute and an oxygen saturation of 100%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac injury, and elevated lactate levels, indicating tissue hypoperfusion. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and his renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show diffuse airspace disease, which has improved, but small bilateral pleural effusions are still present. There is no evidence of pneumothorax.

The patient's medical history includes ACS, unstable angina, and coronary ischemia, and he is at high risk of developing cardiac complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial flutter with frequent runs of atrial fibrillation, and he has a high risk of developing cardiac arrest due to compromised cardiac output.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to compromised lung function.
3. Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results show elevated lactate levels, indicating tissue hypoperfusion, which can lead to sepsis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is at risk of developing renal failure.
5. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial flutter with frequent runs of atrial fibrillation, and he is at risk of developing cardiac tamponade due to compromised cardiac output.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that he receive close monitoring and treatment to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows -> done
   - goal Is/Os even today, ensure UOP > 50 cc/hr
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course,
   today day [**3-31**]
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today -> done
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%, PEEP 10 -> will
   wean PEEP incrementally as able
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of
   208 (CK 1099). ECG demonstrating dynamic changes, concerning initially
   for left main or proximal LAD ischemia given STE in aVR and V1.  Most
   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD
   anterolaterally with new LAD from leftward axis on intial
   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg
   - Hold on plavix, heparin gtt, ACE-I, BB given hypotension and concern
   for ruptured AAA.
   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down, will
   stop cycle
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,
   LV appears to be able to handle increased wall tension, an encouraging
   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension
   and pulmonary edema with BNP 2769 even with ARF.
   - TTE noted above.
   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Now has evidence of
   a.flutter.
   - Telemetry
   - failed DC cardioversion yesterday, will attempt again today on 12
   lead
   - start amio in interim, 150 mg bolus, 1 mg/min for 6 hours, 0.6 mg/min
   for 18 hours
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.  Concern today with 9
   point drop in Hct.  Will repeat Hct, consider repeat CT abdomen
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   - CT CAP non-contrast, transfuse 2 units PRBCs today
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia- etiology includes heparin vs. consumptive, no
   evidence of DIC on exam
   -  will monitor, hold heparin for now
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with
   normal serum potassium level at OSH. This may be in setting of 5 units
   PRBC transfusion. Patient did not receive succinylcholine for RSI.
   Alternatively, this could be rhabdomyolysis given elevated
   transaminases and ARF in setting of statin therapy, although this
   appears less likely. ECG with concerning changes including peaked T
   waves V1-3 and borderline prolonged PR interval.  Now resolved, pt
   requiring K+ in setting of significant UOP
   .
   # Transaminitis: Unclear etiology with unknown baseline, although this
   may be secondary to hypotension, acute renal failure, or
   rhabdomyolysis. Resolving.  Toxicology screen negative.
   - Trend LFTs -> cont to be elevated, stable
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
   be end organ damage in setting of shock or contrast induced
   nephropathy, although less likely given timing.
   - Trend creatinine, electrolytes -> creatinine stable 1.4 on admission,
   now 1.8, also encouraging
   - Repeat UA, urine electrolytes, and urine eos.
   - Obtain baseline labs from PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] NAC and NaHCO3 for CIN prophylaxis.
   .
   # Acidosis: Patient with mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory
   acidosis. Now resolved, pt has primary metabolic alkalosis
   - Trend pH, electrolyes, ABG
   - decrease minute ventilation as able
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Concerning for infectious process, although worsening
   leukocytosis could also be caused by chemical pneumonitis or ACS.
   - Trend fever curve, WBC
   - Antimicrobial therapy as above.
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF
   ACCESS: PIV
   PPx: Heparin SQ, famotidine

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure remains low, with a systolic blood pressure of 118 mmHg and a diastolic blood pressure of 69 mmHg.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has mixed respiratory failure, with hypoxia and hypercarbia. His oxygenation and ventilation have improved with aggressive diuresis and volume-cycled assist control.
* Cardiac concerns: The patient has significant TnT elevation, indicating myocardial damage. His ECG shows dynamic changes, including STE in aVR and V1, which resolved with time. His left heart cath results show moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 107 K/uL, which is low.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient has a potassium level of 7.8 mmol/L, which is high.
* Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, with a peak CK of 2350 IU/L.
* Acidosis: The patient has a mixed non-gap acidosis and respiratory acidosis, which has resolved.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has a white blood cell count of 13.3 K/uL, which is elevated.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Cardiac complications: The patient's myocardial damage and moderate to severe MR may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
* Thrombotic complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and hyperkalemia may increase the risk of thrombotic events, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
* Infectious complications: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated liver enzymes may indicate an underlying infection, which could worsen if not properly treated.
* Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or respiratory failure.

The patient requires close monitoring and treatment of his underlying conditions to prevent these potential complications.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN

   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows -> done
   - goal Is/Os even today, ensure UOP > 50 cc/hr
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)

   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department (ED) due to hypotension and respiratory failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His condition has been complicated by atrial flutter, which has been treated with cardioversion attempts. He has also developed mixed respiratory failure, which is being managed with aggressive diuresis and volume-cycled assist control. His cardiac biomarkers have been elevated, suggesting possible coronary ischemia or infarction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Unstable AAA: The patient's hypotension and shock may be due to an unstable AAA, which could rupture and lead to life-threatening bleeding.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and decreased cardiac output may be due to cardiogenic shock, which could be caused by coronary ischemia, infarction, or heart failure.
3. Sepsis/SIRS: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein may indicate an infectious process, which could lead to sepsis or SIRS.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels suggest acute renal failure, which could be due to end-organ damage, contrast-induced nephropathy, or other causes.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and hypercarbia may be due to respiratory failure, which could be caused by pneumonia, aspiration, or other conditions.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial flutter and possible coronary ischemia or infarction may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which could be life-threatening.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium levels may be due to rhabdomyolysis, statin therapy, or other causes, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
8. Transaminitis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may be due to hypotension, acute renal failure, or other causes, which could lead to liver damage or failure.
9. Leukocytosis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count may be due to an infectious process, which could lead to sepsis or SIRS.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The plan is to continue aggressive diuresis and volume-cycled assist control to manage his respiratory failure and cardiac output. His cardiac biomarkers will be closely monitored, and he will be treated for possible coronary ischemia or infarction. His electrolyte levels will be monitored, and he will be treated for hyperkalemia if necessary. His liver enzymes will be monitored, and he will be treated for transaminitis if necessary. His leukocytosis will be monitored, and he will be treated for sepsis or SIRS if necessary.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 10173**] is a 69 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for HTN
   and hyperlipidemia transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] from an OSH admitted to the CCU
   for hypotension and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was hypotensive to SBP 80s at OSH, at transfer,
   and in the [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  He became increasingly hypotensive to 70s/50s
   post-emergent intubation, and has required intermitent levophed since
   transfer.  Unclear etiology, although concerning for unstable AAA,
   possible recent dynamic changes.  Potential etiologies include
   cardiogenic shock or distributive shock from sepsis/SIRS physiology or
   medications.  Bedside echo by cardiology fellow in ED did not show
   decreased LVEF but with moderate to severe MR with unknown baseline,
   which if new could be the etiology to patient's symptoms.  Repeat TTE
   showed worse LVEF on lower dose levophed.  In addition, volume
   rescucitation in setting of suspected ruptured AAA with 5 units PRBCs
   and 3L IVF likely has caused volume overload leading to decreased
   cardiac output and pulmonary edema from decompensated heart failure.
   SIRS/sepsis could be in the setting of aspiration event during emergent
   intubation or TRALI.
   - Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix 20 mg / hr.  Goal net (-) [**2-29**]
   liters today as BP, MAP, levophed allows -> done
   - goal Is/Os even today, ensure UOP > 50 cc/hr
   - Maintain MAP>60, CVP>12 (intubated)
   - Treat for aspiration pneumonia versus chemical pneumonitis with vanco
   and cefepime (both renally dosed) and flagyl. Likely 7 day course,
   today day [**3-31**]
   -  f/u pending sputum cultures
   - f/u blood cultures and sputum cultures
   - Discussed with blood bank fellow, will fill out transfusion reaction
   form and send pink top -> will repeat type and cross
   - attempt to wean levophed today -> done
   .
   # Mixed respiratory failure: Patient with possible hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure. Hypoxia may have been secondary to
   excessive volume overload in setting of volume rescuscitation and
   worsened MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 509**] from transfusion (i.e. TRALI) or aspiration event.
   Patient was difficult to ventilate in ED requiring vecuronium, and
   remained difficult to ventilate with significant auto-PEEP and
   breathstacking when not paralyzed.  Hypercarbia likely caused by
   fentaynl for back pain, although unclear if patient has history of
   obstructive lung disease.  Pt oxygenation and ventilation has improved
   markedly in setting of aggressive diuresis.
   - Consider restarting vecuronium with adequate sedation in order to
   optimize respiratory mechanics
   - Continue volume-cycled assist control with goal to increase minute
   ventilation to blow off CO2 and wean FiO2 and PEEP.  If patient remains
   difficult to oxygenate may require continued paralytics and APRV.
   - Recheck ABG with vent changes, currently FiO2 50%, PEEP 10 -> will

   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with significant TnT elevation to 2.68 with MB of

   recent ECG with largely resolved STE, but with persistent STD

   presentation.  Left heart cath results as above.  Possible
   revascularization in future if patient improves clinically.
   - ASA 325, atorvastatin 80 mg

   - Cycle cardiac biomarkers -> peak CK 2350, now trending down, will
   stop cycle
   - pt becomes hypertensive with agitation, and in setting of known AS,

   sign
   .
   # Pump: Concerning for decompensated heart failure given hypotension

   - aggressive diuresis as above
   - Check ScVO2, CVP.
   - right heart cath -> increased filling pressures and PCWP 25
   .
   # Rhythmn: Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Now has evidence of
   a.flutter.
   - Telemetry
   - failed DC cardioversion yesterday, will attempt again today on 12
   lead
   - start amio in interim, 150 mg bolus, 1 mg/min for 6 hours, 0.6 mg/min
   for 18 hours
   .
   # AAA: Currently does not appear to be ruptured.  Concern today with 9
   point drop in Hct.  Will repeat Hct, consider repeat CT abdomen
   - Follow-up with vascular surgery regarding timing of intervention
   - Trend hct, maintain active T+S, crossmatch
   - maintain good BP control
   - CT CAP non-contrast, transfuse 2 units PRBCs today
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia- etiology includes heparin vs. consumptive, no

   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Uncertain etiology at this time, although patient with

   .

   # Acute renal failure: Unclear etiology witih unknown baseline. Could
